awd_titl_txt: Homotopical Methods in Higher Representation Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The study of symmetry is a fundamental tool for understanding the world around us, as well as the mathematical frameworks we use to describe it.  As we push the boundaries of our understanding of mathematics and explore the frontiers of theoretical physics, it is becoming increasingly clear that a more refined notion of symmetry is required for the next generation of theories.  The mathematical exploration and development of these types of "higher" symmetries reveals structure and form in any system where they are present, reducing degrees of uncertainty in these system and bringing progress within reach.  While a great deal of progress has been made developing these higher symmetries, the razor's edge of current understanding has revealed that the most exciting applications will require a more flexible theory than has been previously developed.  This project will fill this knowledge gap by providing a robust approach to higher symmetries, capable of describing more complex phenomena and supplying the requisite framework to facilitate the most pressing applications. This award will also support the training and professional development of graduate students and postdocs.
 
This project utilizes homotopical methods to expand existing technology in the field of higher representation theory.  The primary aim is to expand the notion of categorified quantum group from its additive framework to a more robust and homotopically flavored theory that is better adapted for solving the most pressing open problems in the area.  In particular, such a framework will shed light on tensor products of higher representations, lead to a richer higher representation theory that allows for infinite dimensional representations, and provide direct applications to stable refinements in link homology.  This award will also support the training and professional development of graduate students and postdocs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project undertook an in-depth exploration of the influential role symmetry plays in our comprehension of the fundamental structures inherent in low-dimensional surfaces. The Principal Investigator (PI) established a resilient interconnection between these diverse disciplines, where strategies employed in one domain can offer valuable insights into the other, and reciprocally so. By applying the theoretical lens of categorification, the PI revealed hidden structures, using them as a powerful tool to enrich our understanding of these domains.


Intellectual Merit:
More precisely, this project achieved a cross-disciplinary synthesis between certain unexpected branches of mathematics and theoretical physics. It illustrated how Heegaard Floer homology, a highly effective tool used for examining the structure of low-dimensional topology, manifests an intricate symmetry that is depicted by an advanced categorical structure associated with super Lie theory. The discovery of these unforeseen interconnections allowed us to further correlate this theory with structures observed in theoretical physics, which are employed in the computation of scattering amplitudes (specifically, the amplituhedron). This outcome led to the unearthing of a new geometric layer associated with cyclic hyperplanes and facilitated the discovery of additional correlations within the realm of representation theory.


Furthermore, the project unveiled how novel constructions emerging from the study of low-dimensional topology can be effectively employed in the exploration of topological quantum computation. This research underscored how the inception of new nonsemisimple theories can contribute to the emergence of topological phases of matter, potentially leading to significant advancements in the realm of fault-tolerant quantum computation.

Broader Impacts

This project not only enriched our understanding of complex mathematical structures but also served as a valuable platform for training the next generation of STEM professionals. Throughout the award period, the Principal Investigator (PI) provided mentorship to five graduate students, two of whom were women pursuing careers in mathematics. Furthermore, the PI offered guidance to four postdoctoral researchers, all of whom have since secured academic research positions. By supporting undergraduate research, this project granted invaluable hands-on research experience to several students, further contributing to the development of a STEM-skilled workforce.


The project's influence also extended beyond academia into the broader scientific community. The PI collaborated with Joshua Sussan to pen a widely-read article, "An Invitation to Categorification", which successfully makes the advanced concepts of categorification accessible to a wide-ranging audience. This exemplifies the PI's commitment to public science communication. 
Moreover, the PI remained an active contributor to the academic community by participating in multiple graduate student workshops and delivering a remarkable 22 invited lectures worldwide. This consistent level of engagement demonstrates the PI's commitment to disseminating knowledge and fostering a global exchange of ideas.
